metadata.case_name: M/s. J. Burman & Co. v. Union of India

facts.text: Respondent Union of India advertised in Indian Trade Journal for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. of coconut oil.

Tender accepted by respondent on August 31, 1949, concluding contract for supply of 170-1/2 Cwt. coconut oil conforming to specification No. IM.1370(d) at Rs. 89/6/- per Cwt., delivery ex-godown Calcutta by 39-9-49 or earlier.
Contract governed by general conditions of contract Form W.S.B. 133, including arbitration agreement.
Disputes arose regarding the contract and were referred to two arbitrators appointed by the parties in pursuance of arbitration agreement.
After considerable arbitration proceedings, appellant objected to arbitrators' jurisdiction on ground that there was no concluded contract.

Respondent filed petition in Court of First Class Sub-Judge at Delhi against appellant under sections 33 and 28 of Arbitration Act, 1940, seeking declaration of concluded contract containing valid arbitration agreement and extension of time for arbitrators.
Appellant defended that no concluded contract existed and court had no jurisdiction under section 28 or 33.
Trial judge found concluded contract proved, valid arbitration agreement, court jurisdiction, declared valid reference, granted one month's extension to arbitrators.
Appellant filed revision petition in High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh, which confirmed trial court's findings and held petition competent under sections 28 and 33, dismissed revision.
Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by special leave.

Acceptance letter dated August 31, 1949 stated: 'Your offer is hereby accepted... subject to your depositing 10% as security... The contract is concluded by this acceptance and formal acceptance of Tender will follow immediately on receipt of Treasury Receipt.'
Tender subject to conditions in Form W.S.B. 133; Clause 4(a) makes security deposit a condition subsequent at option of Secretary; Clause 4(b) treats failure to deposit as breach of contract.
Arbitrators heard matter at length, proceedings reached stage for award when appellant raised no contract plea, refusing to apply under section 33, causing stalemate.

legal_issues.text: Construction of sections 32 and 33 of Arbitration Act, 1940: Whether court has jurisdiction to entertain petition by party affirming existence/validity of arbitration agreement.
Whether there was a concluded contract between the parties, given acceptance letter 'subject to your depositing 10% as security' and general conditions making it subsequent.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in holding trial court had jurisdiction to entertain respondent's petition under sections 33 or 32; only challengers to arbitration agreement can apply under section 33.
No concluded contract as acceptance letter made security deposit a condition precedent via 'subject to your depositing 10% as security', varying general conditions.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 7 Contract Act; Clauses 4(a), 4(b) Form W.S.B. 133

respondent_arguments.text: Concluded contract existed as per accepted tender under Form W.S.B. 133 containing valid arbitration agreement; petition competent under sections 28 and 33.

court_reasoning.text: Sections 32 and 33 bar suits on existence/validity of arbitration agreement; section 32 implies court's inherent jurisdiction to entertain applications affirming existence where suit barred, to avoid anomaly; section 33 not exhaustive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of sections is to prevent abuse by requiring petitions to specified courts; affirming party can apply under implied power from section 32.

court_reasoning.text: Petition in substance seeks declaration on arbitration agreement validity, as challenge to main contract common to both; substance over form; arbitration clause distinct yet enforceable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If no concluded contract, no arbitration agreement; prayer falls within section 32 bar.

court_reasoning.text: Acceptance letter read as whole is absolute: states 'offer accepted', calls for immediate deposit per clause 4(a), ends 'contract concluded by this acceptance'; security deposit condition subsequent, not precedent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No substantial variation from general conditions; tender for immediate supply.

holdings.text: Court has jurisdiction under implied power from section 32 to entertain petition affirming existence/validity of arbitration agreement; petition competent.
Concluded contract exists between parties containing valid arbitration agreement.

precedents_cited.relevance: Arbitration clause distinct from other contract clauses; can survive contract end.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. M. Gulamali Abdulhussain & Co. v. Messrs. Vishwambharlal Ruiya
precedents_cited.relevance: Court has inherent jurisdiction to entertain petitions barred by section 32.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Adamjee Hajee Dawood & Co., Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Suit not barred if not solely challenging arbitration agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Bar on suits for existence/validity of arbitration agreements; applications to court; jurisdiction; extension of time.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Acceptance must be absolute and unqualified.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court and trial court: trial court had jurisdiction to entertain the petition under sections 32 and 33 read together, and there was a concluded contract containing valid arbitration agreement; one month's extension to arbitrators stands.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration of concluded contract and valid arbitration agreement; extension of time to arbitrators granted by trial court upheld.

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding any law for the time being in force, no suit shall lie on any ground whatsoever for a decision upon the existence, effect or validity of an arbitration agreement or award..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes section 32, central to jurisdiction issue.

key_quotes.text: "The contract is concluded by this acceptance and formal acceptance of Tender will follow immediately on receipt of Treasury Receipt."
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Key language in acceptance letter showing absolute acceptance.

key_quotes.text: "reading the letter as a whole we do not think that the Courts below have erred in coming to the conclusion that this letter amounts to an absolute and unqualified acceptance"
key_quotes.speaker: court
